John Edward : Languages indispensable to global citizens

Independent schools in Scotland have a track record of academic excellence , which continued in 2018 with once again excellent reviews , along with individual and group success in sports , art , music and other collaborative ventures .

With more than 30,000 students across Scotland , these schools , represented by the Scottish Council of Independent Schools ( SCIS ) , are striving to offer their students and parents the best level of service .
Independent schools are designed to prepare students – for secondary education , including at universities , for their desired career and for their role as a global citizen .
In the education sector , we have the opportunity to develop and implement a tailor-made school curriculum , noting that modern languages are still popular and desirable in schools .
Nelson Mandela once said this : “ When you speak to a person in the language he understands , you get your mind . ”
When you talk to him in his own language , it goes to his heart . ”
This is an impressive illustration of the fact that we cannot rely only on the English language if we are to build relations and trust with people from other countries .
This year ’ s audit results show that languages are at the top of the tables with the highest standing rates in independent schools .
68 percent of students who have studied foreign languages have reached the so-called Higher grade A class A .

The data collected by SCIS ’ s 74 member schools showed that 72 % of students reached a “ Higher grade A ” in Mandarin , while 72 , 69 , and 63 respectively reached grade A among the students who learned German , French and Spanish .
This shows that independent schools in Scotland are promoting foreign languages as essential skills that children and young people will undoubtedly need in the future .
Language subjects rank the same in independent schools and elsewhere as MINT subjects ( mathematics , information technology , science , and technology ) .
A 2014 survey by the UK Employment and Qualifications Commission found that 17 % of the reasons why employers had difficulty filling vacancies were due to a lack of language skills .
As a result , language skills are becoming increasingly necessary to prepare young people for their professional future .
With more promising employment opportunities that require languages , these skills are essential in a globalised world .
Regardless of the career that someone chooses when he has learned a second language , he will have a real advantage in the future with a lifetime ability like this .
By allowing people to communicate directly with people from abroad , a multilingual person will automatically be ahead of the competitors .

According to a YouGov survey of more than 4,000 adults in the UK in 2013 , 75 % were unable to speak a foreign language well enough to talk , and French is the only language spoken at a two-digit percentage , namely 15 % .
That is why the current investment in language teaching is important for today 's children .
When children learn to speak several languages – particularly those of developing countries – they will have better chances of finding meaningful employment in the labor market .
The schools in Scotland are different in terms of their language .
Some schools focus on traditional modern languages , while others will teach the most important languages for the UK in 2020 , such as Mandarin or Japanese .
Whatever your child ’ s interest , there will always be a number of languages available in independent schools , with teachers specialized in this field .

Independent schools in Scotland want to provide a learning environment that is well prepared for children , and they should be given the necessary tools for their success , whatever the future may bring .
In today ’ s global business world , languages are undeniably still important for the country ’ s future , and that must also be reflected in education .
Indeed , modern languages should really be regarded as “ international communication skills . ”
Independent schools will continue to offer young people in Scotland this choice , diversity and quality .
Il faut bien le faire .
John Edward is director of the Scottish Council of Independent Schools .
